    Application for a dancehall license shall be made to the city clerk's office on such form or forms as may be prepared by the city clerk from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1(12-127), 11-20-2000) 
Sec. 10-68. - Requirements. 
    A dancehall must meet the following requirements at all times in the operation of the business: 
(1)  No operator or stockholder, member or partner, if the owner or lessee is other than an individual, or security employee or contractor of the operator of a dancehall shall have been convicted of any felony or crime of moral turpitude within a period of ten years prior to the date of application. 
(2)  The building or structure in which the dancehall is located shall meet all applicable building, electrical, plumbing, sanitary, and fire codes, statutes, and regulations of both the city and the state. 
(3)  No dancehall shall be located in any geographical location within the city zoned under any residential zoning classification. 
(4)  A dancehall shall cease operations at 1:00 a.m. and require all guests or patrons to leave the premises prior to 2:00 a.m. with the exception of personnel required to clean up the premises. Notwithstanding the foregoing, on January 1 the dancehall need not be closed and vacated by customers, patrons or other persons until 2:00 a.m. 
(5)  During all times of operation, the dancehall must have a minimum of one security person and at least two security personnel for each 100 persons present while a dance is in progress. A minimum of two security personnel shall be required for any dancehall event where alcoholic beverages are served or allowed. Security personnel must be at least 21 years of age with no criminal convictions other than moving traffic violations. Security personnel must wear clothing while on duty which clearly identifies them as security. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1(12-128), 11-20-2000) 
Sec. 10-69. - Public safety commission review of application. 
    The clerk of the city shall within five days of the receipt of such completed application transmit the same to the public safety commission for purposes of determining whether the applicant meets the objective criteria of the mayor and council set forth in section 10-68. For purposes of such application, the applicant must propose to locate its business in a completed building or structure at the time the application is made. The public safety commission shall have the right to require that each applicant or stockholder, member or partner, if the applicant is other than an individual and security employee or security contractor of the proposed applicant be fingerprinted and consent to a criminal background investigation by city personnel. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1(12-129), 11-20-2000) 
Sec. 10-70. - Findings of public safety commission. 
    The public safety commission shall consider any application for a dancehall within 60 days of the date of transmittal of the application by the city clerk to the public safety commission. The public safety commission shall report its findings to the city clerk. If the public safety commission shall report to the city clerk that the applicant meets all of the requirements of section 10-68 then the city clerk shall issue a business license to the applicant upon payment of the license fee. If the public safety commission shall find an applicant does not meet the requirements of section 10-68, then the clerk shall notify the applicant in writing as to the requirements which have not been met and the city clerk shall not issue a business license to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1(12-130), 11-20-2000) 
Sec. 10-71. - Compliance with public safety commission requirements prerequisite to issuance of license. 
    Any applicant who shall not have met the requirements of section 10-68 upon investigation provided in section 10-69, shall have a period of 60 days from the date of receipt of written notice from the city clerk as provided in section 10-70 to comply with all of the requirements of section 10-68 and to appear before the public safety commission and show that such requirements have been met. If the public safety commission shall concur with the applicant that such requirements have been met within the 60-day period allowed, the public safety commission shall report said finding to the city clerk who shall then issue a business license to the applicant upon the applicant's paying the required license fee. If the applicant shall be found by the public safety commission to have failed to meet all requirements of section 10-68 within the 60 days allowed, then the city clerk shall notify the applicant that a business license cannot be issued upon its application. Upon such notification the application shall be precluded from further consideration by the public safety commission for a period of one year from the date of such notification. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1(12-131), 11-20-2000) 
Sec. 10-72. - Dancehalls operated exclusively for minors. 
    Any person desiring to operate a dancehall exclusively for minors, whether or not an admission fee is charged, must have in attendance at least one security person and two security personnel per 50 persons at all times that a dance is in progress. Security personnel must be at least 21 years of age with no criminal history other than moving traffic violations. Security personnel must wear clothing while on duty which clearly identifies them as security. A dancehall shall terminate operation on or before 11:00 p.m. and the participants therein shall be limited to minors between the ages of at least 14 years of age and under the age of 18. No alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on the premises where a dancehall for minors is operated. 
(Ord. No. 00-20, § 1(12-132), 11-20-2000) 
ARTICLE IV. - SPECIAL EVENTS 

Sec. 10-101. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter: 
    DDDA. The Downtown Dalton Development Authority. 
    Downtown business district. The downtown business district shall have the following boundaries: 
    All that tract or parcel of land, situate, lying and being in the City of Dalton, Whitfield County, Georgia, more particularly described as follows: 
    Beginning at a point where the L & N Railroad (main track) intersects the northern right-of-way of Hawthorne Street; then westerly along the northern right-of-way of Hawthorne Street to its intersection with the eastern right-of-way of Selvidge Street; then southerly along the eastern right-of-way of Selvidge Street to its intersection with the northern right-of-way of Waugh Street; then westerly along the northern right-of-way of Waugh Street to its intersection with the western right-of-way of Thornton Avenue; then southerly along the western right-of-way of Thornton Avenue to its intersection with the southern right-of-way of Morris Street; then easterly along the southern right-of-way of Morris Street to the point where the southern right-of-way of Morris Street intersects the L & N Railroad (main track); then northerly along the L & N Railroad (main track) to the point of beginning. 
    Producer. Any person, group of persons, organization, association, club, or other entity responsible for planning, producing and conducting an event. 
    Special event. The term "special event" or "event" shall mean any organized activity having as its purpose entertainment, recreation and/or education, such as a festival or celebration, foot or vehicle race, parade or march, rally or assembly which takes place on a public street, sidewalk or right-of-way, or occurs on private property and impacts government services on public rights-of-way. 
    Vendor. Any person or persons who engage in the sale to the public of any food or food products, goods, services, or merchandise of whatever nature from any location, either mobile or stationary, on a temporary itinerant basis on any public street, sidewalk, or right-of-way. The definition of vendor, as used in this chapter, shall not be construed to include or prohibit a permanent business located within the downtown business district from displaying goods or merchandise on a public sidewalk immediately in front of and adjacent to the permanent business structure so long as such displays do not impede the normal flow of pedestrian traffic and so long as other laws and ordinances pertaining to such business or displays are complied with. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-102. - Permits. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person, group, organization, association, club or other entity to conduct or cause to be conducted any special event in downtown business district without having obtained a valid permit for such event. 
(b)  Geographic limitation; responsibility for police and sanitation service. A special event shall be limited to the downtown business district within which the event is to take place and the producer of a special event shall be responsible for the provision of police and sanitation services within the boundaries of the event for a period commencing 30 minutes prior to the scheduled start of the special event and concluding when the area is cleared of all activities and structures related to such event. 
(c)  Time limitation. Except for clearing of the area, no special event shall be allowed to continue beyond the time approved on the permit for the event. 
(d)  Delineation of boundaries; preservation of areas for circulation. The outermost boundaries of the special event shall be fully and clearly delineated on a map, which shall be no smaller than eight and one-half by 11 inches in size, and attached to the application for a permit. All public streets and/or sidewalks within and adjacent to such area(s) shall be clearly identified. The DDDA shall require, as part of the approval for the event, that areas no less than five feet in width shall be designated and preserved for public circulation and access to adjoining business establishments outside the area(s) delineated for the event. 
(e)  Maps for walks or runs. The producer of a special event such as a walk or run, as to which the provisions of subsection (d) above would not be practicable, shall submit with the application for a permit a map, which shall be no smaller than eight and one-half by 11 inches in size, showing the exact route of the course for the walk or run. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-103. - Application; fee. 
(a)  A producer of a special event shall make application for a permit for such event at the office of the DDDA on a form prescribed by the city. Application forms may be obtained from the office of the DDDA. 
(b)  An application for a special event should be filed at least 60 days prior to the date the event is scheduled to occur. However, no application shall be accepted earlier than one year prior to the date of the event. 
(c)  A nonrefundable application fee of $25.00 shall be paid at the time the application for a permit is filed. Such fee shall be payable to the DDDA by cash, money order, or cashier's check. Provided, however, no producer with a principal place of business located within the downtown business district shall be required to pay the application fee. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-104. - Identification of producer. 
    The producer of an event, if a group or organization, shall be fully identified on the application. However, a special event permit shall be issued only to an individual person, who may be the actual producer or a designated agent of the producer, and such individual person shall be jointly and severally responsible with the producer for compliance with all provisions, including all financial requirements, of this chapter and other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-105. - Administrative review; waiver. 
(a)  The DDDA shall cause the application to be circulated to the city administrator's office, the police department, the fire department, the public works department, the building inspector's office and to each government department and/or other agency whose services the DDDA determines would be affected by the nature and activities of the proposed event. Each such department or agency shall review the application and note the services which it will be required to perform, the number of personnel to perform such services, the length of time to perform such services, the cost to perform such services, and any other information which will assist the DDDA in facilitating the event and services required. 
(b)  The city administrator shall approve, approve with conditions or deny any such application no later than 30 days after the date of his receipt of the application unless the applicant requests additional time to provide further information to the DDDA. The failure of the city administrator to act on the application as provided herein as of said 30-day period or the agreed extended date shall be deemed an approval of the application. 
(c)  Decisions of the city administrator that adversely affect or aggrieve any applicant may be appealed to the mayor and council. Any such appeal shall be by written petition filed in the office of the city clerk within seven days after the final decision by the city administrator. 
(d)  The mayor and council shall perform a review of the application no later than 30 days after the date the written petition is received by the city clerk. No additional information may be submitted on the issue unless it specifically requested by the mayor and council. The mayor and council may approve, approve with conditions or deny the application. The failure of the mayor and council to act on the application as provided herein as of said 30-day period shall be deemed an approval of the application and its decision shall be final. 
(e)  If the applicant is a qualified nonprofit or governmental entity, the city administrator is authorized to waive any special condition or other requirement of this article that will not affect the public health, safety, or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003; Ord. No. 11-01, § 1, 2-21-2011) 
Sec. 10-106. - Special conditions on permit. 
    Each department of the government reviewing an application may recommend in writing certain conditions or restrictions as deemed necessary to facilitate the event, to comply with other laws or regulations, and/or to ensure the safety, health and welfare of the community. Unless expressly waived under section 10-105, the recommendations of the departments shall be imposed as a part of the permit and such special conditions so imposed shall be construed to have the full force and effect of law as a provision of this chapter. A violation of such conditions or restrictions shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-107. - Final approval of permit; minimum review period; appeal. 
(a)  If the application has not been denied by the city administrator, the DDDA is authorized to approve and issue a permit for a special event after considering all comments and conditions of the reviewing departments and agencies as well as other information pertaining to the proposed event as described on the application, and after the payment of all applicable fees and costs. 
(b)  A minimum of 30 days shall be allowed for the administrative review of an application and the issuance of a permit. 
(c)  The DDDA shall either issue or deny the permit no later than 30 days following the date the completed application is filed. Failure of the DDDA to act within the time provided herein shall be deemed a denial of the permit. If the permit is denied, the producer shall be notified in writing of the denial and the reason(s) for the denial. 
(d)  The denial of a permit may be appealed to the mayor and council. Any such appeal must be filed with the city administrator within 15 days of the date the application was denied. The mayor and council may approve the application, with or without conditions, or deny the application. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-108. - Emergency issuance of permit. 
    In extraordinary circumstances, the city administrator or his designee shall be authorized to waive or otherwise expedite any or all of the review process and to issue a special event permit upon payment by the producer of all applicable fees and costs for such event. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-109. - Permit fees. 
(a)  The fee for a permit to conduct a special event shall be based on all services to be provided by the government for such event and shall be equal to the estimated actual cost to the government to provide such services unless expressly waived by the city administrator. The initial permit fee shall be the aggregate of the estimated costs of such services calculated by each government department. If, at the conclusion of the event, the cost of government services is greater than the initial payment, the producer of the event shall be billed for the difference. Failure to pay the outstanding amount within 30 days of the billing date shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(b)  The initial permit fee must be paid in full prior to the issuance of a permit and no later than 72 hours prior to the date of the event. 
(c)  The fees required in this section shall be in addition to any other fees which may be required by any other ordinances or regulations that might be applicable. 
(d)  No producer of any special event, except as otherwise provided for, shall be exempt from the payment of the appropriate fees and charges required under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-110. - Liability. 
    The producer of any special event and its designated agent, if applicable, shall hold harmless the city, the DDDA, their respective officers, employees and agents from liability of damages arising from any acts or omissions emanating from a special event. The producer shall, as a condition precedent to obtaining a permit, obtain such releases and waivers as may be required by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-111. - Vendors. 
(a)  Sales permitted. The sale of food, including the sale of beer and/or wine as provided herein, or any merchandise or services of any type by a vendor shall be allowed as a component of a special event provided such vendor is approved and authorized in writing by the producer of the event and has paid all required taxes and fees for applicable permits or licenses. All sales shall be conducted in accordance with such conditions and limitations as shall be imposed in writing by the producer and submitted as part of the application for a permit. 
(b)  Authorization of vendors. The producer of a special event shall have sole responsibility and authority to allow or disallow sidewalk or street vending as a component of an event and to designate the location and activities of such vendors. Except as otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful for any vendor to engage in such business at any location or in any manner not authorized by the producer of the event. 
(c)  Identification required. Any vendor authorized by the event producer shall be required to prominently display on his or her person a badge identifying the vendor as an authorized participant in the event. Such identification shall be not less than three inches by three inches, shall state that the bearer is an official participant in the event, and shall bear the signature of the producer of the event. 
(d)  Permit not required. Vendors authorized by the producer of an event as a component of the event shall not be required to obtain any separate vendor permit to operate during the period of the event. 
(e)  Unauthorized vending prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any vendor not authorized by the producer of a special event as provided under this section to engage in such business within a distance of 25 yards of such event from one hour before until one hour after the event. This prohibition shall not apply to merchants located within the downtown business district; however, such merchants shall display and sell merchandise on the street or sidewalk within the boundaries of the special event during the special event time period in compliance with all other laws and ordinances pertaining to such business or displays. 
(f)  Food sales. The vendor of any food, whether hot or cold, as a part of a special event shall be subject to all rules and regulations of the county health department. It shall be the responsibility of the producer of an event to assure compliance with this section by such vendors. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-112. - Sale of beer and/or wine. 
    Subject to written approval by the city administrator or his designee beer and/or wine may be dispensed and consumed at a special event subject to the following conditions: 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Festival. A special event sponsored by a nonprofit civic organization as defined in section 6-111, where the majority of the net proceeds of the special event benefit a charitable cause or the promotion of the city. 
    Festival area. The area within which beer and/or wine may be dispensed and consumed during a festival. 
(1)  Primary festival area. The boundaries of the primary festival area are as follows: Beginning at the point where the sidewalk on the eastern right-of-way of Selvidge Street abuts the northern right-of-way of Crawford Street, then extending north along the sidewalk on the eastern right-of-way of Selvidge Street to its intersection with the sidewalk on the southern right-of-way of King Street, then east along the sidewalk on the southern right-of-way of King Street to the eastern right-of-way of Pentz Street, then north along the eastern right-of-way of Pentz Street to the sidewalk on the northern right-of-way of King Street, then west along the northern right-of-way of King Street to its intersection with the sidewalk on the eastern right-of-way of Selvidge Street, then north along the sidewalk on the eastern right-of-way of Selvidge Street to the entrance to the BB&T parking lot, then west across Selvidge Street to the sidewalk on the western right-of-way of Selvidge Street, then south along the sidewalk on the western right-of-way of Selvidge Street to the northern right-of-way of Crawford Street, the east across Selvidge Street to the point of beginning. 
(2)  Alternative festival area. Any area within the C-3 commercial district that is approved by the city administrator, the chief of police and the director of public works. 
    Special outdoor area. The area, within a special event, that is not a festival where beer and/or wine may be dispensed and consumed. 
(b)  Conditions applicable to festivals only. 
(1)  The producer of a festival shall supply wristbands for purchase by attendees that wish to consume beer and/or wine within the festival area. The wristbands shall be of a type that cannot be removed without tearing. The wristbands must be attached at the point of purchase by representatives of the producer. 
(2)  No wristband shall be sold or given away to an attendee without first determining that the attendee is at least 21 years of age. 
(3)  No beer or wine shall be dispensed to an attendee who is not wearing the proper wristband for the event. 
(c)  Conditions applicable to special outdoor areas only. 
(1)  The producer of a special event that is not a festival may apply for one special outdoor area within the delineated boundaries of the event. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  The special outdoor area shall be placed at a location and of a size approved by the city administrator or his designee. 
(4)  The application for a special event where a special outdoor area is requested shall include, in addition to a map identifying the outermost boundaries of the event, a map no smaller than 8 1/2 x 11 inches in size, clearly identifying the area, including all public streets and sidewalks within and adjacent to the area, where the special outdoor area is proposed. The application shall include the proposed size for the special outdoor area. The application also shall contain a description of the methods and structures that will be used to secure and separate such area from other public areas as required in subsection (2) above. 
(d)  Conditions applicable to festivals and special outdoor areas. 
(1)  The dispensing of beer and/or wine at a special outdoor area shall be restricted to the holder of a valid alcoholic beverage license to sell retail beer and/or wine by the drink. The name of such licensee(s) shall be required as a part of the application for a special event permit. 
(2)  The producer of the special event shall provide, at the producer's expense, at such security personnel as required by the chief of police, or his designee. 
(3)  The festival area or the special outdoor area shall be conspicuously posted at all times at each point of entrance/exit with signs stating the following: 
"The possession of alcoholic beverages beyond this point is prohibited." 
The letters of such signs shall be not less than three inches in height and one-half inch in width and shall be in black letters on a contrasting light background. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for patrons of the outdoor area of a special event in which beer and/or wine is permitted to bring into or take outside the designated area any alcoholic beverage or to furnish any alcoholic beverage to any person outside the designed area where beer and/or wine is permitted. 
(5)  The fee for a permit to dispense and/or consume beer and/or wine at a special event shall be $300.00. 
(6)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, any person dispensing and/or consuming beer and/or wine in accordance with this section shall comply with all other laws and ordinances pertaining to the sale, possession and consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 04-14, § 1, 4-5-2004; Ord. No. 09-10, § 1, 4-20-2009; Ord. No. 13-07, § 1, 8-19-2013; Ord. No. 14-04, §§ 1, 2, 8-4-2014) 
Sec. 10-113. - Glass containers prohibited. 
    The use of glass containers within the area of any special event shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-114. - Police services. 
    Traffic and crowd control shall be provided by the city police department and the number of officers and/or special arrangements shall be determined by the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-115. - Toilet facilities. 
    The producer of a special event shall be required to provide temporary outdoor toilet facilities at any event at which 200 or more persons are expected to be in attendance. The number of toilets and their locations shall be determined by the director of public works or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-116. - Entertainment. 
    Musical entertainment shall be provided in a manner consistent with the peace and good order of the community. The producer of the event shall be responsible for full compliance with the noise ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-117. - Tents, stages, etc. 
    Tents, arbors, stages, grandstands or other temporary facilities constructed or erected as a part of a special event shall be approved by the director of the building inspector's department. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-118. - Street closing. 
    The complete or partial closure of any street, sidewalk or other public way as a part of a special event shall be approved by the city administrator, or his designee, in consultation with the police and public works departments. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-119. - Banners, signs, etc. 
    Temporary, noncommercial banners or signs may be permitted overhead across public streets for the purpose of designating "starting" and "finish" lines for a race. Small banners, pennants, signs or other decorations which do not interfere with vehicular or pedestrian traffic, and which do not damage or deface any tree or public structure, may be allowed as part of a special event. Approval of the city administrator shall be obtained by the event producer for any banners or signs permitted in this section. The producer of the event shall be responsible for the removal of such banners, pennants or decorations within 48 hours after the close of the event. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-120. - Duration of permit. 
    No permit issued under this chapter shall be valid prior to or past the date of the special event for which it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-121. - Cessation of activities. 
    The safety, health, welfare and good order of all citizens and the community shall be first and foremost and every special event shall be conducted in such manner to comport with this standard. The chief of police or fire chief, or their respective designees, may terminate any activity, whether a part of or the entire event, which does not meet this community standard. Upon notification to the event producer to cease any activity by a person so authorized, it shall be unlawful for such producer and/or any participants to permit such activity to continue. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-122. - Picketing and demonstrations, etc. 
    Any person, group or organization engaged in any picketing, demonstrations, assembly, gathering, procession or other activity protected by the U.S. Constitution shall be prohibited from blocking the ingress and egress of any public or private place. Any person, group or organization engaged in such activities is required to make application as set forth in section 10-103. However, any such person, group or organization shall be exempt from the permit requirement in section 10-102 and the fees set forth in section 10-103 and section 10-109. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Sec. 10-123. - Parades; funeral processions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any parade or procession conducted under the supervision and direction of a funeral director in conjunction with any funeral. 
(Ord. No. 03-09, § 1, 5-5-2003) 
Secs. 10-124-10-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SIDEWALK CAFES 

Sec. 10-130. - Definition. 
    Sidewalk cafe means an area of food or beverage service located outside, but connected with, a part of, and adjacent to, an indoor restaurant or cafe located in the downtown Dalton area. 
(Ord. No. 11-07, § 1, 7-18-2011) 
Sec. 10-131. - Conditions for sidewalk cafes. 
(a)  Sidewalk cafes shall be so located and maintained that the following portion of the contiguous sidewalk shall remain unused and unobstructed: 
(1)  On Hamilton Street, where the streetscape has been completed, at least a ten-foot portion of the sidewalk measured from the face of the Hamilton Street curb perpendicularly toward the property line of the adjacent indoor restaurant. 
(2)  On all other streets within the downtown district, where streetscape has been completed, at least an eight-foot wide portion of the sidewalk measured from the face of the curb of the street perpendicularly toward the property line of the adjacent indoor restaurant. 
(3)  A minimum of four feet shall be provided at all times between the sidewalk cafe area and the curb or nearest obstacle on all streets to allow for continuous unobstructed pedestrian traffic on the sidewalk. 
(4)  Permanent plantings, city owned waste receptacles, streetlight poles, and other permanent fixtures along the sidewalk must be considered when determining the boundaries set forth in a permit. 
(b)  Any special construction proposed to encroach upon or occupy any of the public right-of-way shall be permitted only by prior approval of such plans by the city building inspector. 
(c)  The sidewalk cafe operator shall at all times ensure that: 
(1)  No encroachment on public rights-of-way, other than as stated in this section, shall be allowed to exist. 
(2)  All general provisions and clean community regulations of the refuse collection and disposal provisions are complied with. 
(Ord. No. 11-07, § 1, 7-18-2011) 
Sec. 10-132. - Regulations. 
    Except as otherwise provided, a sidewalk cafe shall comply with the following: 
(a)  Limitations on area. The area in which a sidewalk cafe is operated shall abut the outside front wall of the restaurant of which it is an extension and shall not extend in either direction beyond the outside front wall of the restaurant. Use of any storefront and/or sidewalk areas in front of premises immediately next door shall be permitted only to the extent permitted by a written agreement between the owners of such adjacent premises. Adjacent property owners may not charge a fee or receive compensation for the use of the sidewalk areas in front of their property. 
(b)  Divider required. The area permitted for a sidewalk cafe shall be separated by a divider in compliance with section 6-10 of the Code which will serve to contain crowds and maintain the boundaries of the cafe. The system shall be designed and constructed such that it resists movement and can be disassembled and removed if necessary. Such divider shall be not less than three feet and no more than four feet in height. All tables and chairs shall be located totally within the limits of the divider. It shall be the responsibility of the sidewalk cafe operator to maintain the divider in its exact/approved location at all times. 
(c)  Sanitation. It shall be the responsibility and duty of the sidewalk cafe operator to maintain the area in a clean, neat, and orderly manner at all times. It shall also be the responsibility of the sidewalk cafe operator to properly clean the area as specified by the city public works department. All tables and chairs are to be kept clean, sanitary, safe, and in structurally sound condition at all times. 
(d)  Removal of furnishings and suspension of operation. All tables, chairs, and dividers of a sidewalk cafe shall be removed from the public sidewalk area from time to time and outside operations suspended as required by the city for sidewalk upkeep or for such other purposes as the city may determine, in its sole discretion for such purposes as, but not limited to: 
(1)  Any permitted special event; 
(2)  Any street, sidewalk or utility construction; 
(3)  Any emergency situations; or 
(4)  The protection of the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(e)  Furnishings. Furnishings shall not be secured to lamp posts, streetlights, trees or any other public street fixtures. Furnishings may not be stacked or stored outside on the public right-of-way at any time. 
(1)  Fences/barriers. A physical barrier in compliance with [this] Code shall serve to maintain the boundaries of the sidewalk cafe. Flower boxes or planters may be used to define the corner boundaries of the area. 
(2)  Menu boards and signs. Menu boards, both portable and on walls, shall be subject to sign permit approval and shall comply with [this] Code. 
(3)  Umbrellas. Each table may be equipped with an umbrella that, when open, shall extend to at least the same diameter as the table it serves and shall be anchored with a weighted base. Any umbrella protruding into public space shall be positioned at a minimum height of seven feet. Each umbrella shall be maintained in good, clean, and operable condition. 
(4)  Tables and chairs. Materials-Tables and chairs shall match and be made of safe, sturdy and durable material, such as wood, steel, or wrought iron. All furniture shall be commercial grade and manufactured for outdoor commercial use. Vinyl tablecloths are not recommended. Small round or square tables shall seat no more than four people. Use of larger tables may be granted provided that all clearance requirements are met. Round tables shall be no larger than three feet diameter. Square tables shall be no larger than three feet wide and rectangular tables no more than three × four feet. 
(f)  Landscaping. Flower boxes or planters may be used to define the corner boundaries of the seating area. The combined height of the planters and live plants shall not exceed four feet from sidewalk grade and no wider than two feet at the base. The planting areas shall be planted with seasonal blooming or ornamental evergreen live plants year round. The permit holder shall maintain flower boxes and planting areas. The flower boxes, planters and trash receptacles shall be portable and made of safe, durable and attractive materials such as wood, steel or colored concrete. 
(g)  Hours of operation. A sidewalk cafe may be open for breakfast, lunch and/or dinner and any combination thereof, consistent with the business's normal hours of operation. 
(h)  Guidelines. The city shall adopt standards and guidelines for consideration without amendment to this article. 
(Ord. No. 11-07, § 1, 7-18-2011) 
Sec. 10-133. - Liability and insurance. 
    Sidewalk cafe operators shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and its officials and employees from claims and liability arising out of the use of a sidewalk cafe. The sidewalk cafe operator shall obtain insurance covering the use of a sidewalk cafe and name the city as an additional insured with respect to such insurance. The city shall prepare guidelines with respect to any indemnification and insurance requirements of sidewalk cafe operators. 
(Ord. No. 11-07, § 1, 7-18-2011) 
Sec. 10-134. - Americans with Disabilities Act. 
    All sidewalk cafes shall fully comply with all requirements of the Americans with Disabilities Act as currently existing or as may be hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 11-07, § 1, 7-18-2011) 
Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Power of mayor and council to pass ordinances relating to stock straying at large, § 4-11. 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 50; pets in mobile home parks, § 70-66 et seq. 
State Constitution reference- Animal control by municipalities, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(3). 
State Law reference- Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; notification of bites by animals, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-4; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-7. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Animal control board. 
(a)  There is created for the city an animal control board to consist of five adult resident citizens of the city and to be appointed for staggered terms of four years each by the mayor and council. The mayor and council shall in its appointments designate one appointee as chairman who shall hold the position of chairman throughout his term. The animal control board shall elect a chairman pro tem who shall act in the absence of the chairman or in any vacancy in the position of chairman, as well as a secretary who shall keep and certify minutes and proceedings of the animal control board. 
(b)  Upon the death, resignation or other event creating a vacancy in the seat of any member of the animal control board, the mayor and council shall fill the vacancy by appointing a qualified individual to fill the unexpired term of the vacating member by passage of an appropriate resolution. For purposes of determining the time of the regular expiration of any term of office of any member of the animal control board, the first year for an initial appointee shall be deemed to run from the date of initial appointment to the board until the first regular meeting of the mayor and council in January, 1992. Thereafter, a year shall be deemed to run from the first regular meeting of the mayor and council in January of any calendar year until the first regular meeting of the mayor and council in the immediately succeeding calendar year. 
(c)  No member of the animal control board shall be reappointed by the mayor and council to succeed himself for a successive term of service on the animal control board, except that members initially appointed for a term of three years or less or filling a vacancy in a term of three years or less may be reappointed for one full term. 
(d)  Three members of the animal control board shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of any business or proceedings before the animal control board, and a vote of a majority of members present at any meeting of the board is required to take any action. 
(e)  The chairman of the animal control board shall conduct all meetings of the animal control board, except in his or her absence when the meeting shall be conducted by the chairman pro tempore. 
(f)  Each member of the animal control board shall have one vote on all matters to be decided. 
(g)  No member of the animal control board shall be paid any salary or compensation for his or her service. 
(h)  The sole responsibility of the animal control board shall be to conduct a hearing upon the request of a dog's owner as to the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24. 
(i)  Upon receipt by the city clerk of a request for a hearing pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-24(c), the city clerk shall schedule a hearing that is within 30 days of the receipt of the hearing request and shall notify the dog owner by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery of the date, time and place of the hearing. Said notice shall be mailed at least ten days prior to the hearing date. 
(j)  At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and to present evidence and in addition thereto the animal control board shall receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as the animal control board may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify, or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. 
(k)  Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the animal control board shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail or statutory overnight delivery of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-74); Ord. No. 10-20, § 1, 12-6-10) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and authorities, § 2-236 et seq. 
Secs. 14-2-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ANIMAL CONTROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq. 

Sec. 14-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Domesticated animal means any animal raised so as to live in close proximity to humans. Such animals include dogs and cats, as well as varieties of poultry, livestock or reptiles. 
    Domesticated animal at large means any domesticated animal not under the restraint of a person capable of controlling it on or off the premises of the owner. 
    Owner means any person who owns, possesses, harbors or keeps or knowingly permits an animal to be harbored or kept or has an animal in his care or who permits an animal to remain on or about his premises for more than three days. 
    Public nuisance means any animal that unreasonably annoys humans, endangers the life or health of other animals or persons or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, other than its owner, to enjoyment of life or property. The term "public nuisance" means and includes but is not limited to any animal that: 
(1)  Is found at large; 
(2)  Damages, the property of anyone other than its owner; 
(3)  Chases vehicles; 
(4)  Attacks other domestic animals; 
(5)  Unprovoked, attacks pedestrians or passersby; or 
(6)  Has been found by the animal control officer to be a public nuisance animal by virtue of being a menace to the public health, welfare or safety. 
    Vaccination means a protection against rabies by inoculation with antirabies vaccine, given in an amount sufficient to provide immunity from rabies for a minimum of one year. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-20)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Dogs damaging livestock or poultry, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-4; nuisances, O.C.G.A. tit. 41; nuisances in cities, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 
Sec. 14-27. - Animal control officer. 
(a)  There is created the office of animal control officer, which officer shall enforce this article. The city may at any time and from time to time contract or enter into an agreement with the county or any other municipality, county or combination thereof for staffing the position of animal control officer. 
(b)  The animal control officer is authorized to issue citations to persons violating this article for trial in the municipal court of the city upon such citations. 
(c)  The animal control officer, as well as employees and agents of the animal control officer and persons under his control and supervision, are empowered to seize animals as required by this article so long as the animals are within the city. The employees and agents of the animal control officer and persons under his control and supervision shall have the right to go on private property within the city for the purposes of enforcing this article, provided it is necessary for such purpose. Further, the animal control officer may set and issue fines as provided in this article when the person chooses to waive his right to a hearing in municipal court. The animal control officer shall have the authority to issue citations and subpoenas to witnesses and to require their appearance in municipal court on any matter relating to the enforcement of any of the sections contained in this article. 
(d)  The animal control officer may be contacted after normal business hours by digital beeper and shall respond in the following circumstances: 
(1)  In response to a report of a person bitten within the last hour by an animal; 
(2)  In response to a report of an animal being injured and in distress; 
(3)  In response to a request of the city police department for assistance in restraining an animal which threatens the safety of law enforcement personnel or others; 
(4)  To investigate charges of animal cruelty when such investigation cannot reasonably be postponed until normal office hours; and 
(5)  In response to such other situations which, in the judgment and discretion of the animal control officer, require an immediate response in order to protect the public. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-21)) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-121 et seq. 
Sec. 14-28. - Penalties. 
    Any owner whose animal is found to be in violation of any of the sections of this article may be cited by the animal control officer or through a sworn complaint alleging any violation by a person who has personal knowledge of such violation and who can identify the owner of the animal involved or the premises where the animal is located. Any owner found guilty of violating this article shall be fined as follows: 
(1)  If the animal is reclaimed within the five-day waiting period as set forth in section 14-33, the penalty shall be a certificate for $55.00, redeemable by any participating veterinarian, from the city clerk for the sum of $50.00 once the animal has been sterilized by the veterinarian or a fine of $55.00 to be determined at the discretion of the animal control officer or the municipal court judge. 
(2)  If the animal is not reclaimed, the owner shall be fined not less than $100.00 for the first offense. 
(3)  Except for a first-time offense under subsection 14-32(a), other violations of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100.00 and/or community service of up to 40 hours. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-25); Ord. No. 05-14, § 1, 9-19-2005) 
Sec. 14-29. - Municipal court jurisdiction. 
    The municipal court of the city shall have jurisdiction over all alleged violations of any section of this article and shall have all powers granted to it which are necessary and incident to the hearing and disposition of matters brought before the court, such powers to include the authority to issue citations and summons for witnesses. The following persons have standing to file complaints for violations of this article: 
(1)  The animal control officer or his agent. 
(2)  Other law enforcement officers. 
(3)  Public health officials. 
(4)  Individuals with personal knowledge of the violation upon filing a sworn complaint with the municipal court. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-27)) 
Sec. 14-30. - Unlawful interference by third parties. 
(a)  No person within the city shall, without the knowledge or consent of the owner, hold or retain possession of any animal that he does not own for more than 72 hours without first reporting the possession of such animal to the animal control officer. This subsection shall not apply to those nonprofit organizations whose purpose is the protection of animals. 
(b)  No person within the city shall willfully cause an animal to be in violation of any section of this article. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to attack, assault or in any way physically or verbally threaten or interfere with the animal control officer or his agents in the performance of those duties required to enforce this article. 
(d)  Any motor vehicle operator who strikes or runs down any animal within the city shall immediately give notice to the animal control office or appropriate law enforcement agency. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to tamper with, destroy or take any trap which has been set by the animal control officer or his agents. 
(f)  No person within the city shall perform a cruel act on any animal nor shall any person harm, maim or kill any animal, except for the animal control officer or his agent as provided under subsection 14-33(d), or attempt to do so, except that a person may: 
(1)  Defend his person or property or the person or property of another from injury or damage being caused by an animal; or 
(2)  Kill any animal causing injury or damage to any livestock or poultry. 
The method used for killing the animals shall be designed to be as humane as is possible under the circumstances. A person who humanely kills a dog under the circumstances described in this subsection shall incur no liability for such death. The penalty for a violation under this subsection shall be a fine of not less than $100.00 for the first offense. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-26)) 
Sec. 14-31. - Vaccinations. 
    All dogs and cats within the city must be vaccinated against rabies with the vaccine and in the manner prescribed by the state veterinarian and the state board of health. Vaccinated dogs and cats shall be provided with a proper tag. The owner of every dog or cat vaccinated shall obtain from a veterinarian a certificate of such information. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-22)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-5. 
Sec. 14-32. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  The following activities shall be prohibited, and the owner shall be subject to the issuance of a warning from the animal control officer or municipal court upon the first offense; subsequent offenses shall be fined pursuant to section 14-28. 
(1)  Animals running at large. It is unlawful for any owner to cause or allow an animal to run at large in or on any public property, vacant lot, or private property within the city without consent of the property owner. 
(2)  Animals disturbing the peace. It is unlawful for any person to allow any animal in his possession or control within the city to persistently or continuously bark, howl or make noise common to their species or otherwise to disturb the peace and quiet of the surrounding neighborhood. It shall likewise be unlawful to keep or maintain such animals in such a manner as to produce noxious or offensive odors, or to otherwise endanger the health and welfare of surrounding inhabitants. 
(3)  Dog control. No person owning or otherwise having a dog in his care, charge, control, custody or possession within the city shall cause, permit or allow such dog to be in or upon any public area unless such dog is under restraint by leash or chain. Dogs are prohibited in those areas so designated and posted by the city. 
(4)  Keeping of sick or diseased animals. It is unlawful for any person within the city to own any animal which is seriously sick or injured and not provided proper veterinary care for such animal. This section shall not be construed to include animals under active veterinary care or in veterinary hospitals. 
(b)  The following activities within the city shall be subject to penalty provisions pursuant to section 14-28: 
(1)  Cruelty. It shall be awful to abandon any animal or fail to provide it with sufficient, wholesome and nutritious food and water in sufficient quantities, proper air, shelter space and protection from the weather. No person shall beat, cruelly treat, torment, or otherwise abuse an animal. 
(2)  Animal fights. It is unlawful for any person to promote, stage, hold, manage, conduct, carry on, train for, attend or own any animal for the purpose of participating in any game, exhibition, contest or fight in which one or more animals are engaged for the purpose of injuring, killing, maiming, or destroying themselves, or any other animal. 
(3)  Female dogs or cats in heat. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any female dog or cat to allow the animal to run at large while in heat. 
(4)  Vaccination requirement. All dogs and cats shall have proper tags evidencing vaccination as provided in section 14-31. 
(5)  Destruction of property. No animal shall destroy or damage private or public property. 
(6)  Transporting animals. 
a.  Domesticated animals shall not be left unattended in vehicles without adequate ventilation, or during times of extreme heat or cold. Law enforcement officers who shall come upon a domesticated animal left unattended in any vehicle without adequate ventilation may use reasonable force to remove such animal and transport to the county animal shelter. Any such officer shall leave a written notice bearing the name of the officer and the location where the animal may be claimed; 
b.  Transportation of domesticated animals in the uncovered bed of a pickup truck upon roads with a speed limit of 35 miles per hour or more shall require the animal to be properly secured in an enclosure that is secured safely to the pickup truck. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-23); Ord. No. 05-13, § 1, 9-19-2005; Ord. No. 10-12, § 1, 11-15-2010) 
Charter reference- Power of mayor and council to pass ordinances relating to stock straying at large, § 4-11. 
State Law reference- Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq.; dogs damaging livestock or poultry, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-4; permitting dogs in heat to roam free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; nuisances, O.C.G.A. tit. 41; nuisances in cities, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 
Sec. 14-33. - Impoundment. 
(a)  Any animal seized and impounded under any of the sections of this article shall be detained for a period of five working days. If the ownership of the animal is not determined within that period, the animal shall be disposed of in such a manner as the animal control officer may designate. Any animal seized that is wearing identification tags shall be kept for ten days, and the animal control unit shall attempt to notify the owner by writing or phone if possible. 
(b)  If, at any time during the required waiting period set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the owner indicates to the animal control officer his intention to not reclaim the animal, the balance of the waiting period shall be waived and the animal shall be disposed of pursuant to this section. 
(c)  If, at any time during the required waiting period, examination of the animal by the animal control officer indicates the animal to be severely sick and/or to be a threat to the health of other animals detained in the impoundment, the balance of the waiting period shall be waived and the animal shall be disposed of pursuant to this section. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall prevent the animal control officer from killing an animal when he determines that it is a menace to public safety or to other animals and cannot be impounded with reasonable effort. 
(e)  Any animal not sterilized which is released for purposes of adoption rather than to its owner for redemption shall be required to have a nonrefundable certificate purchased from the animal control officer in the amount of $55.00. This certificate may be redeemable by any participating veterinarian from the city clerk for the sum of $50.00 once the animal has been sterilized by the veterinarian. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-24)) 
State Law reference- Livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-34. - Enclosures for keeping small animals. 
    Other than those animals prohibited in section 14-32, small animals, under ten pounds in weight, and miniature pot bellied pigs may be kept within the city limits, subject to the following: 
(a)  Condition, size. All such animals must be provided with adequate housing and kept in such housing while not within the immediate presence of the owner. The pens or other enclosures wherein animals are kept shall have a solid floor made of cement or other suitable washable material, except when pens are 75 feet or more from the nearest neighbor's residence or place of business. Floor space in all these pens or enclosures, wherever located, must have the following minima: 
1.  Miniature pot bellied pigs, 100 square feet per animal. 
2.  Rabbits, guinea pigs, and all other small animals under ten pounds and not specifically provided for herein, four square feet per animal. 
(b)  Location. Pens or yards where such animals are kept shall be placed at the following minimum distances from any residence or business establishment: 
1.  Distance from any residence, except that of owner, or any business establishment, 50 feet. 
2.  Distance from owner's residence, five feet. 
(c)  Maximum number. The maximum number of such animals which may be kept on a single premises shall not exceed the following: 
1.  Miniature pot-bellied pigs, one. 
2.  All other small animals in any combination, ten. 
(Ord. No. 05-08, § 1, 5-16-2005; Ord. No. 05-14, § 2, 9-19-2005) 
Sec. 14-35. - Shelter/tethering requirements. 
(a)  All domesticated animals shall be provided with proper shelter. Said shelter shall be constructed and maintained to protect the animal from rain, snow, ice, excessive cold or heat, and excessive direct sunlight, and shall be of a size to allow the animal sufficient space to stand, turn around, and lie down in a comfortable position appropriate to the age, size, and health of the animal. 
(b)  Crates specifically designed for domesticated animals shall comply with this section provided such crate is appropriately sized for the animal. 
(c)  Adequate shelter generally shall consist of four walls, a roof, a floor, and an opening of adequate size, based upon the size of the animal. Alternatively, metal or plastic drums may constitute adequate shelter. Such shelter shall be elevated not less than four inches above the ground to prevent the intrusion of water. The provisions set forth herein are in addition to the provisions for small animals as set forth in section 14-34 of this chapter. 
(d)  Inadequate shelter shall include, but not be limited to, boxes, lean-tos, or the areas beneath or upon porches, decks, or crawl spaces. 
(e)  Each domesticated animal shall be provided individual shelter. 
(f)  An owner may confine his or her domesticated animal by tethering such animal with a running cable line or trolley system, attached to stationary objects at either end, and not less than 20 feet in length and mounted not less than six feet nor more than seven feet above ground level. The tethering of a domesticated animal to a single stationary object is prohibited. 
(g)  The length of the tether shall allow access to the maximum available exercise area and shall allow free access to food, water, and shelter. 
(h)  As an alternative to a running cable line or trolley system, an owner may tether a domesticated animal to a single stationary object upon meeting all of the following conditions: 
(1)  The exercise area must consist of a minimum of 500 square feet of area upon the owner's lot or parcel; 
(2)  The tether shall be made of braided or metal cable and may not consist of either a chain or rope; 
(3)  The tether shall be attached to the stationary object by snap hook or other device utilizing a swivel connection; 
(4)  The tether shall allow free access to food, water, and shelter; and 
(5)  The tether shall not allow the animal to leave the owner's lot or parcel. 
(i)  For the purposes of this section the following definitions shall apply: 
    Exercise area shall refer to the unobstructed area within which a domesticated animal may walk or run while tethered without encountering obstacles impeding movement. 
    Trolley system (or running cable line) shall refer to a tethering system consisting of a horizontal cable attached at both ends to a stationary object, typically a vertical post or tree. The horizontal cable shall have stops at each end so as to limit the travel distance and to prevent the domesticated animal from becoming wrapped around the post or tree. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 2, 11-15-2010) 
Sec. 14-36. - Cleanup requirement. 
    The owner of every domesticated animal shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by his or her domesticated animal on public or private property within the city. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 3, 11-15-2010) 
Sec. 14-37. - Sale of dogs and/or cats. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to offer any dog or cat for sale at any flea market or other temporary sales location. 
(Ord. No. 10-12, § 4, 11-15-2010) 
Secs. 14-38-14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BIRD SANCTUARY 

Sec. 14-61. - City designated. 
    The entire area within the corporate limits shall be and is designated and established as a bird sanctuary. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-36)) 
Sec. 14-62. - Hunting generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob or destroy the nests of any such birds or wild fowl within the city limits. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-37)) 
Sec. 14-63. - Nuisance birds. 
    Notwithstanding the other sections of this article, if birds congregate in large numbers in any particular locality to such an extent that they constitute a nuisance or menace to health, the city may authorize the chief of police to abate such nuisance in such manner as he deems best. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-38)) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 50-176 et seq. 
State Law reference- Nuisances, O.C.G.A. tit. 41; nuisances in cities, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5. 
Secs. 14-64-14-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DANGEROUS DOGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 50. 

Sec. 14-91. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the City of Dalton acting by and through its governing authority. 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: 
(1)  Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989; or 
(2)  Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. 
    Dog control officer means the individual selected by the city pursuant to this article to aid in the administration and enforcement of this article. 
    Governing authority means the mayor and council acting in its legislative capacity. 
    Owner means any natural person or legal entity, including but not limited to a corporation, partnership, firm or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. 
    Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property at any time after March 31, 1989. 
    Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog while on the owner's property that is securely confined indoors or securely enclosed in a locked pen, fence or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top. If the dog is enclosed within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be of sufficient height, and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed and secured in such a manner as to prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the fence. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. 
    Records of an appropriate authority means records of any state, county or municipal law enforcement agency; records of any county or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state or local court; records of a dog control officer provided for in the Georgia Dangerous Dog Control law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. 
    Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or physical injury that results in death. 
(b)  A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article. A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article if the injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a wilful trespass or other tort or was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused or assaulted the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-71)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-92. - Authority to contract for services. 
    The city may, at any time and from time to time, contract or enter into an agreement with the county or any other municipality, county or combination thereof for implementation and provision of joint dog control services and for the separate or joint use of personnel, facilities and equipment used in the provision of such services and as authorized by O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22(b). 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-72)) 
Sec. 14-93. - Violations. 
    Any person in violation of this article shall be subject to citation to the municipal court and, upon conviction, the owner of the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall be subject to assessment of the general penalty in section 1-7 as determined by the municipal judge. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-85(b))) 
Sec. 14-94. - Dog control officer. 
    There is established for the city the office of dog control officer who shall have powers, duties and responsibilities as provided in this article and pursuant to the dangerous dog control law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq. Designation of an individual to carry out the duties of dog control officer shall be made by the governing authority, and the individual designated as dog control officer shall serve at the pleasure of the governing authority but pursuant to such administrative supervision and direction as the governing authority may provide from time to time. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-73)) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-121 et seq. 
Sec. 14-95. - Inquiries or investigations. 
    The dog control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiries or investigations are deemed necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-79)) 
Sec. 14-96. - Certificate of registration required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for an owner to have or possess within the city a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with this article. 
(b)  The dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer or the dog control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of the following: 
(1)  A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. 
(2)  The posting of the premises where a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. (The sign posted pursuant to this subsection shall conform substantially to the design provided by the state department of natural resources pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 4-8-25(b)). 
(3)  A policy of insurance in the amount of at least $15,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in the state insuring the owner of the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog or a surety bond in the amount of $15,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in the state and payable to any person injured by the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-75)) 
Sec. 14-97. - Annual fee for certificate of registration. 
(a)  Prior to receiving a certificate of registration for a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog pursuant to this article, the owner of such dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall pay to the city an annual fee of $25.00. 
(b)  At the time of the annual renewal of the certificate of registration, the dog control officer shall require evidence from the owner or shall make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with other sections of this article. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-80)) 
Sec. 14-98. - Effect of issuance of certificate of registration. 
    The city's issuance through its dog control officer of a certificate of registration or renewal of certificate of registration pursuant to this article does not warrant or guarantee nor is it intended to warrant or guarantee to the public at large or to any specific person that the requirements of this article or of the dangerous dog control law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq., are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of issuance of the initial certificate of registration or following the date of any renewal of such certificate. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-78)) 
Sec. 14-99. - Notification required generally. 
    The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-76)) 
Sec. 14-100. - Notice by owner of moving; registration by new resident. 
    The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the dog control officer's jurisdiction. For purposes of this section, the term "jurisdiction" shall mean the corporate limits of the city as established from time to time. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who is a new resident of the state shall register the dog, if the dog is kept within the city, with the dog control officer within 30 days after becoming a resident. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from another county or municipality in the state to the city shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog with the dog control officer within ten days after becoming a resident of the city. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-77)) 
Sec. 14-101. - Certain acts prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but will prevent it from biting any person. 
(b)  It is unlawful and a violation of this article for an owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-81)) 
Sec. 14-102. - Confiscation generally. 
(a)  A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if: 
(1)  The owner does not secure the liability insurance or bond required by subsection 14-96(b)(3). 
(2)  The dog is not validly registered as required by subsection 14-96(a). 
(3)  The dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure. 
(4)  The dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of subsection 14-101(a). 
(b)  A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the dog is: 
(1)  Not validly registered as required by subsection 14-96. 
(2)  Not maintained in a proper enclosure. 
(3)  Outside a proper enclosure in violation of subsection 14-101(b). 
(c)  Any dog that has been confiscated under subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with this article and upon the payment of the reasonable confiscation costs. For purposes of this subsection, the term "reasonable confiscation costs" shall mean the actual cost of capturing, confining and maintaining the dog prior to its actual return to the owner. If the owner does not comply with this article within 20 days of the date the dog was confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-82)) 
Sec. 14-103. - Quarantine after confiscation. 
    The dog control officer, a law enforcement officer or any other person authorized by the dog control officer shall confiscate a dangerous dog immediately and place it in quarantine for the proper length of time as determined by the county board of health and, thereafter, shall see that the dangerous dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner if the dangerous dog either: 
(1)  Attacks or bites a human being under circumstances constituting a violation of this article where the owner of such dangerous dog has a previous conviction for violation of this article and has knowingly and wilfully failed to comply with this article after such first occurrence; or 
(2)  Aggressively attacks and causes severe injury or death to a human being under circumstances constituting a violation of this article after its owner has knowingly and wilfully failed to comply with this article. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-85(a)) 
Sec. 14-104. - Investigation and inquiries of reports; notice of classification generally. 
(a)  Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the city from any law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer or county board of health, the dog control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out this article. In exercising his duties the dog control officer is authorized to enter private lands or enclosures within the city as follows: 
(1)  Upon announcing himself to the property owner, tenant or occupant of the land or enclosure in which the dog control officer requires entry and requesting consent. 
(2)  If the owner, occupant or tenant shall refuse consent to the dog control officer upon his announcement and request for entry, upon search warrant as may be provided by law. 
(b)  When the dog control officer shall classify a dog as a dangerous dog or reclassifies a potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall promptly notify the dog's owner in writing by certified mail to the owner's last known address of such classification or reclassification. Such notice shall be complete upon its mailing. 
(Ord. of 2-1-1999(2), § 1(F)(5-83)) 
Sec. 14-105. - Contents of notice of classification. 
(a)  When the dog control officer shall classify any dog as a potentially dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification, and the notice to the owner shall: 
(1)  Be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address. 
(2)  Include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that form the basis for the dog's classification as a potentially dangerous dog. 
(3)  Be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog. 
(4)  State that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the animal control board. 
(5)  State that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this article on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day in which the owner has a right to request a hearing. 
(6)  Include a form to request a hearing before the animal control board and provide specific instructions for mailing and delivering such request to the board. 
(b)  When a dog is classified as a dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification and the notice to the owner shall: 
(1)  Be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address. 
(2)  Include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that form the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous dog. 
(3)  Be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog. 
(4)  State that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the animal control board.
